G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 28A, and 3.proposition: This Court has proper jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, and 31, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the Berkshire Probate and Family Court issued the existing custody order and the children reside within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has proper jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, and 31, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the Berkshire Probate and Family Court issued the existing custody order and the children reside within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 29.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court as the prior order was entered here and the minor children reside within the jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time order upon a showing of (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (b) that modification is in the best interests of the child. See also *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370–371 (1981); *Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130, 134–135 (2004).

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time order upon a showing of (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (b) that modification is in the best interests of the child. See also *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370–371 (1981); *Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130, 134–135 (2004).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses modification of alimony and child support, not custody or parenting time. It interprets G.L. c. 208, § 28 only for the standard governing modification of child support (“as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require”), and nowhere articulates a two-prong test of (1) material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) best interests of the child for custody/parenting-time modifications. Thus, while Schuler is relevant to support-modification standards, it does not provide authority for the specific custody/parenting-time proposition claimed.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. Resolution of the issue rests in the judge’s sound discretion. Buchanan v. Buchanan, 353 Mass. 351, 352 (1967). An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1976, c. 279, § 1.”

*Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 13.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting-time order upon a showing of (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (b) that modification is in the best interests of the child. See also *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370–371 (1981); *Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130, 134–135 (2004).
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 13.support_reasoning: This opinion is a post-divorce modification case, but it concerns modification of child support and alimony under G.L. c. 208, § 37 and § 34 principles, not modification of custody or parenting-time orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The court discusses the standard for modification of support (material change in circumstances and judicial discretion) but says nothing about custody/parenting-time or the § 28 best-interests standard. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modifying custody or parenting time under § 28.
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 13.relevant_excerpt: “Our review recognizes that, in fashioning an appropriate modification judgment, the probate judge enjoys considerable discretion, and the judgment will not be reversed unless it is ‘plainly wrong.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). … However, ‘where the trial court has previously passed on the issue of alimony in the divorce judgment, the correct course of action … is the post-divorce complaint for modification, implicating the traditional test of a material change in circumstances.’ Buckley v. Buckley, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 716, 719 (1997).”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: In determining custody and parenting time, “the happiness and welfare of the children” and their best interests are paramount.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: In determining custody and parenting time, “the happiness and welfare of the children” and their best interests are paramount. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840–842 (2003).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that under G.L. c. 208, § 30, the phrase “upon cause shown” means that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and then emphasizes that the best interests of the children are the central and paramount concern. In discussing the removal standard, the court notes that although the custodial parent’s interests matter, the child’s best interests remain controlling, tying those interests to the child’s happiness and welfare. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that the children’s happiness, welfare, and best interests are paramount in custody and related determinations.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that…[t]he words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”}

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.proposition: In determining custody and parenting time, “the happiness and welfare of the children” and their best interests are paramount. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840–842 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the “best interests of the child” as the governing custody standard and describes it as the long-standing, paramount consideration in Massachusetts custody and visitation decisions. It cites prior cases (including Yannas) and traces the historical development of the best-interests standard, confirming that the child’s welfare is the controlling concern in custody determinations, consistent with the proposition stated.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers to impose conditions on parenting time to protect a child’s best interests, including supervised visitation or restrictions on contact with third parties when necessary to safeguard the children from harm or exposure to domestic violence or instability.

*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u20.proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers to impose conditions on parenting time to protect a child’s best interests, including supervised visitation or restrictions on contact with third parties when necessary to safeguard the children from harm or exposure to domestic violence or instability. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; *Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658–659 (2002); *Malachi M. v. Quintina Q.*, 483 Mass. 725, 736–738 (2019).
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u20.support_reasoning: Blixt concerns the constitutionality and construction of the grandparent visitation statute (G.L. c. 119, § 39D), not the court’s equitable powers to condition or restrict a parent’s own parenting time under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31. The case discusses when and how a court may order visitation for grandparents over parental objection, focusing on presumptive parental autonomy and a required showing of harm, but it does not address supervised visitation, restrictions on a parent’s time, or limits on a child’s contact with third parties as conditions of parenting time. Thus it does not support the specific proposition cited.
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u20.relevant_excerpt: “More specifically, to succeed, the grandparents must allege and prove that the failure to grant visitation will cause the child significant harm by adversely affecting the child’s health, safety, or welfare. The requirement of significant harm presupposes proof of a showing of a significant preexisting relationship between the grandparent and the child. In the absence of such a relationship, the grandparent must prove that visitation between grandparent and child is nevertheless necessary to protect the child from significant harm.”

*Malachi M. v. Quintina Q.*, 483 Mass. 7.proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers to impose conditions on parenting time to protect a child’s best interests, including supervised visitation or restrictions on contact with third parties when necessary to safeguard the children from harm or exposure to domestic violence or instability. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; *Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658–659 (2002); *Malachi M. v. Quintina Q.*, 483 Mass. 725, 736–738 (2019).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: Massachusetts law explicitly recognizes the significance of domestic violence and a child’s exposure to abusive or coercive behavior in custody determinations.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.proposition: Massachusetts law explicitly recognizes the significance of domestic violence and a child’s exposure to abusive or coercive behavior in custody determinations. See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 31A (requiring consideration of abusive behavior and creating a rebuttable presumption against awarding custody to a parent who has a pattern or serious incident of abuse); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595–597 (1996); *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610, 620–622 (1986).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the role of domestic violence and a child’s exposure to that violence in custody decisions. The SJC endorses the view that abuse of any family member must be considered in determining the child’s best interests, emphasizes the distinct harm to children who witness or are victims of domestic violence, and requires explicit findings on the effect of such violence on the child and on the appropriateness of the custody award. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts law recognizes the significance of domestic violence in custody determinations.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.relevant_excerpt: “We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm.… Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610,.proposition: Massachusetts law explicitly recognizes the significance of domestic violence and a child’s exposure to abusive or coercive behavior in custody determinations. See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 31A (requiring consideration of abusive behavior and creating a rebuttable presumption against awarding custody to a parent who has a pattern or serious incident of abuse); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595–597 (1996); *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610, 620–622 (1986).
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns care and protection and the standard for removing children from parental custody; it does discuss extensive intra-family violence (including the father’s violence toward the mother) as part of the unfitness analysis. However, the court does not articulate any general rule about “domestic violence” as such, nor does it state that exposure to abusive or coercive behavior is a specifically recognized, required factor in custody determinations, and it certainly does not reference G.L. c. 208, § 31A (which was enacted later). Thus, while the facts involve abuse, the case is not authority for the explicit statutory/domestic-violence-focused proposition claimed.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610,.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the conclusions of various professionals involved with the family ‘raise[d] legitimate concerns about [the father’s] capacity to be a competent parent’ by reason of the history of abuse and aggressive behavior in the father’s upbringing and the father’s repeated loss of self-control and propensity toward anger. In addition, the judge found that the father failed to see the need for continued therapy and that the father did not understand the ‘seriousness of the family’s proclivity for violence.’ The judge found that return of the children would undermine the gains realized by the parents….”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 840\u201.proposition: The Court may modify parenting arrangements where the new living situation or the presence of other adults in a parent’s home presents risk to the children, causes instability, or undermines their safety and emotional well-being. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 840–843; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 265–266 (2001); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184–186 (2006).

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court may modify parenting arrangements where the new living situation or the presence of other adults in a parent’s home presents risk to the children, causes instability, or undermines their safety and emotional well-being. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 840–843; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 265–266 (2001); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184–186 (2006).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not support the proposition that a court may modify parenting arrangements based on risks or instability from a new living situation or other adults in the home. Instead, Rosenthal reverses a change of custody and holds that relocation and a temporary, court-imposed change in custody are not, by themselves, material and substantial changes justifying modification, and it notes there was no evidence that the mother’s remarriage or new household arrangement was detrimental to the child. The case thus undercuts, rather than supports, using such factors alone as a basis for modification absent proof of harm or risk.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements… To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker…. The father argues… that the mother’s remarriage and move… would implicitly seem to be a change of circumstances… There is nothing in the findings to support the contention that the mother’s remarriage had a detrimental impact on Caleb.” (51 Mass. App. Ct. at 265–266 & n.5).

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u.proposition: The Court may modify parenting arrangements where the new living situation or the presence of other adults in a parent’s home presents risk to the children, causes instability, or undermines their safety and emotional well-being. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 840–843; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 265–266 (2001); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184–186 (2006).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the best-interests standard to a removal/relocation and resulting modification context, expressly relying on facts about the children’s living situation and the presence and conduct of other persons in the mother’s home (the step-sibling) as reasons to deny the requested change and maintain the existing parenting arrangement. The court upholds the judge’s reliance on evidence that the move would be detrimental to the children’s educational and emotional stability and that alleged misconduct by a step-sibling “weighed against increased time in the mother’s household.” This aligns with the proposition that courts may modify or decline to modify parenting arrangements when a new living situation or other adults in a parent’s home present risk, instability, or undermine the children’s safety and emotional well‑being.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u.relevant_excerpt: “After some time, and a four-day trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal to New Hampshire in the manner requested by the mother was not in the best interests of the children… The judge found that Chelmsford schools were preferable… that uprooting the children would be detrimental to their interests; that the move would cause a reduction of the father’s parenting time… that misconduct allegations against a step-sibling weighed against increased time in the mother’s household… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: The existence of a criminal record for assault and battery and a prior abuse prevention order is strongly indicative of a history of violence or domestic abuse, which bears directly on the safety and welfare of children exposed to that individual. See G.L. c. 209A; G.L. c. 208, § 31A; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595–597.

*Schuler*, 382 Mass. at 370\u2013371.proposition: The introduction of this New Partner, and the pattern of conduct described above, constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances since the March 15, 2021 order, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and Massachusetts case law. See *Schuler*, 382 Mass. at 370–371; *Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. at 134–135; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 840–842.

*Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. at 134\u2013.proposition: The introduction of this New Partner, and the pattern of conduct described above, constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances since the March 15, 2021 order, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and Massachusetts case law. See *Schuler*, 382 Mass. at 370–371; *Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. at 134–135; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 840–842.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 840\u201.proposition: The introduction of this New Partner, and the pattern of conduct described above, constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances since the March 15, 2021 order, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and Massachusetts case law. See *Schuler*, 382 Mass. at 370–371; *Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. at 134–135; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 840–842.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31, 31A.proposition: This material change in circumstances directly implicates the best interests of the minor children and requires this Court to re‑examine the existing parenting-time arrangement in order to ensure the safety and welfare of Emily and Lucas. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184–186.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 31, 31A.proposition: The best interests of Emily and Lucas require that they be protected from exposure to violence, threats of violence, or a pattern of aggressive or intimidating behavior in their home environment. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 31, 31A; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595–597.

*Blixt*, 437 Mass. at 658\u2013659.proposition: The Court has both the authority and the responsibility to impose reasonable conditions on parenting time when necessary to protect the children, including requiring supervised parenting time or prohibiting contact between the children and particular adults who pose a risk to them. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A; *Blixt*, 437 Mass. at 658–659; *Malachi M.*, 483 Mass. at 736–738; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. at 265–266.

*Malachi M.*, 483 Mass. at 736\u2013738.proposition: The Court has both the authority and the responsibility to impose reasonable conditions on parenting time when necessary to protect the children, including requiring supervised parenting time or prohibiting contact between the children and particular adults who pose a risk to them. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A; *Blixt*, 437 Mass. at 658–659; *Malachi M.*, 483 Mass. at 736–738; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. at 265–266.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. at 265–266
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court has both the authority and the responsibility to impose reasonable conditions on parenting time when necessary to protect the children, including requiring supervised parenting time or prohibiting contact between the children and particular adults who pose a risk to them. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A; *Blixt*, 437 Mass. at 658–659; *Malachi M.*, 483 Mass. at 736–738; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. at 265–266.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31A.proposition: A modified order limiting the New Partner’s presence around the children during the Defendant’s parenting time, or in the alternative requiring that the Defendant’s parenting time be supervised by an appropriate third‑party supervisor or professional visitation center, is narrowly tailored, reasonably necessary, and consistent with the statutory mandate to protect children from exposure to abuse and domestic violence. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31A; *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. at 620–622; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184–186.

*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. at 62.proposition: A modified order limiting the New Partner’s presence around the children during the Defendant’s parenting time, or in the alternative requiring that the Defendant’s parenting time be supervised by an appropriate third‑party supervisor or professional visitation center, is narrowly tailored, reasonably necessary, and consistent with the statutory mandate to protect children from exposure to abuse and domestic violence. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31A; *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. at 620–622; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184–186.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184\u20.proposition: A modified order limiting the New Partner’s presence around the children during the Defendant’s parenting time, or in the alternative requiring that the Defendant’s parenting time be supervised by an appropriate third‑party supervisor or professional visitation center, is narrowly tailored, reasonably necessary, and consistent with the statutory mandate to protect children from exposure to abuse and domestic violence. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31A; *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. at 620–622; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184–186.
